subject: Extending JUnit with first-class dependencies
msgSnippet: Welcome everyone, I am new here and hope that this is the right place to announce a novel JUnit extensions. If not, please point us to the proper place.
messageBody:
Welcome everyone,

I am new here and hope that this is the right place to announce a novel JUnit extensions. If not, please point us to the proper
place.

JExample is an extensions that introduces dependencies. But unlike eg TestNG, we go beyond mere dependencies. We use
dependencies to pass the "instance under test" from one the test method to the next. If test B depends on A, the return value of A
can be used as B's fixture. And if A test fails, B and all other dependees of A are skipped and marked as white. We show in an
empirical study (accepted at the XP2008 conference) that JExample improves performance, shortness of test methods, and defect
localization.

Let me give an example :)

Testing a stack is not trivial, there is an intrinsic dependency between pushing and popping elements. An element can not be
popped without pushing it first. Intrinsic dependencies are evil. If there is a bug in push, both push's and pop's test fail, even if
there is no bug in pop! Therefore, we declare that testPop depends on the successful outcome of testPush. When running the
tests, the return value of testPush is used as the fixture of testPop.

@Test
public Stack testPush() {
Stack s = new Stack();
s.push("Foo");
assertEquals(1, s.size());
return s;
}

@Test
@Depends("testPush")
public void testPop(Stack s) {
s.pop("Foo");
assertEquals(0, s.size());
}

Using JExample, each test method is a comprehensive constructor that creates an example instance of the unit under test. That is
also why JExample is called JExample. The idea of example-driven testing is based on the work of Markus Gaelli.

You can learn more about JExample here

http://www.iam.unibe.ch/~akuhn/blog/2008/04/jexample-quickstart/
http://www.iam.unibe.ch/~scg/Research/JExample/

Download

http://www.iam.unibe.ch/~scg/Research/JExample/jexample-latest.jar

Please give it a try (JExample is a seamless extension of JUnit and even runs with the normal JUnit runner of Eclipse) and let us
know what you think.

cheers,
Adrian
